Issues.Title: Add TagAttribute for component properties
Issues.Body:
While the ParameterAttribute allows a property to be used as a component attribute (ex. where MyParameter is [Parameter], thus `<MyCustomComponent MyParameter=...>`), the TagAttribute allows a property to be used as a component's child tag. Ex. where Template is [Tag]:

```
    <MyCustomComponent>  
        <Template>  
            ...
        </Template>  
    </MyCustomComponent>  
```

This is subtly suggested in #404. A possible side-effect is that a property can be both [Parameter] and [Tag], allowing it to be used as a component attribute or child tag. Either way, the idea is that the contents, in-line or declarative, are assigned to the property.

In a declaration/usage, it should be an error to use the same [Parameter][Tag] property as both attribute and tag. Either one but not both, so that the ff. is an error:

```
    <MyCustomComponent MyParameterTag=...>  
        <MyParameterTag>  
            ...
        </MyParameterTag>  
    </MyCustomComponent>  
```

Because MyParameterTag is used as both parameter and tag in this declaration, there is no way to know which content to keep. Should it be a design-time or compile-time error?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add TagAttribute for component properties" (#987)

Issues.Title: Target Netstandard2.0 in Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server package
Issues.Body:
Currently the [Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server](https://dotnet.myget.org/feed/blazor-dev/package/nuget/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server) package targets `netcoreapp2.0`.
This prevents aspnetcore webapps targeting the full framework from using it to server blazor client apps.

Is there a specific reason behind this decision?

A proposed change would be to change the targetframework to `netstandard2.0`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Target Netstandard2.0 in Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server package" (#986)

Issues.Title: Blazor potentially no longer client-side technology?
Issues.Body:
Hi,

I watched today's ASP.NET Community Standup stream, and although the Electron demo was impressive, I'm somewhat surprised that the team is now seriously considering changing direction and running Blazor on the server. While there are some valid scenarios (and I think this should definitely be an option in the future), what got me (and others) so excited about this technology was the fact that it is purely client-side framework (webserver serving only static files).

To be honest, I was hoping that by this time (has it been a year since the first Blazor demo?) I would already be writing production apps in what I think is the best UI framework that Microsoft has been working on for quite some time. Wasn't this project supposed to be given a go/no go in May?

Thanks and keep up the great work! Very impressive what such a small team has been able to accomplish so far!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Blazor potentially no longer client-side technology?" (#984)

Issues.Title: dotnet command with path parameter uses parent folder casing
Issues.Body:
To reproduce (note the casing):

1. `dotnet new blazor -o Repro`
2. `dotnet build repro/Repro.csproj`

This fails with a whole bunch of errors about not being able to find the namespace `Repro.Shared`, because the build uses the path name specified in the dotnet build/run/publish command as the namespace name. This means that e.g. MainLayout.g.i.cs *defines* the namespace `repro.Shared`, but everything *uses* `Repro.Shared`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "dotnet command with path parameter uses parent folder casing" (#978)

Issues.Title: Linker enhancements
Issues.Body:
Ways we'd like to improve it in the short term:

* Update to the latest linker tooling. We've heard from the Mono team that they've made many improvements.
* Add and document a simpler mechanism for customising the linker's behavior. The linker already accepts `.xml` config files to control in more detail which types/methods are strippable/retainable. We should make it easier to supply a custom config alongside (or instead of) the default one.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Linker enhancements" (#972)

Issues.Title: Built-in Json isn't compatible with the default serialization in ASP.NET
Issues.Body:
I found that JSON coming from an API controller that uses Entity Framework Core cannot handle the default serialization done by ASP.NET in a few cases.

* `sbyte`, `ushort`, `uint` and `ulong` do not deserialize (ArgumentException)
* `byte[]` content for e.g. `[Timestamp]` properties which are serialized as base64 do not deserialize
* `decimals` outside the range of `double` cq `long` do not deserialize

The first needs a single line changed, the second needs 2 added lines, the third needs two if else statements added.

Would you like me to submit a pull request to fix this?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Built-in Json isn't compatible with the default serialization in ASP.NET" (#966)

Issues.Title: Unable to hit breakpoints in cshtml file - Blazor
Issues.Body:
I am unable to hit a breakpoint in the "Blazor (ASP.NET Core Hosted)" template.

I set a breakpoint in FetchData.cshtml 

    @foreach (var forecast in forecasts)

The breakpoint is set successfully and symbols are loaded (debugger states that breakpoints will be hit). However, when I load /fetchdata, the breakpoint on this line is not hit.

I am able to hit breakpoints in SampleDataController.cs, specifically the WeatherForecasts() method.

Also, markup changes in the CSHTML are not reflected when the page is reloaded.

This differs from my experience with  traditional ASP.NET 4.6.1 MVC web development in Visual Studio where both live mark changes and debugging in razor pages are supported.  

I am using Visual Studio 2017 Preview Version 15.8.0 Preview 2 and have .NET Core 2.1.4 installed.

Admittedly, this may not be a bug ... perhaps it is not something that will ever be planned or something that is not supported at the current time. Out of curiosity, if it is the latter, is this something on the roadmap?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unable to hit breakpoints in cshtml file - Blazor" (#967)
